conclusion: The hemispherical lens has radius R and its centre is O.
MN is a vertical diameter, so rays that arrive perpendicular to MN travel horizontally inside the glass.
Rays enter the glass through the plane surface at the left; because the incidence is normal, they suffer no refraction and propagate horizontally until they meet the curved surface.
Choose Cartesian axes with origin at O: point on surface: (x,y), x²+y²=R², x≥0.
Unit vector of a ray inside the glass v=(+1,0). Unit normal of the spherical surface at (x,y): n=(x/R, y/R).
The incidence angle i (inside the glass) satisfies cos i = v ⋅ n = x/R, sin i = y/R.
Glass to air, refractive index n=4/3.
Critical angle for total internal reflection: sin θc = 1/n = 3/4, θc ≃ 48.6°.
A ray can leave the glass only if i ≤ θc ⟺ sin i ≤ sin θc ⟺ y/R ≤ 3/4.
The usable zone on the spherical surface is the band -3/4 R ≤ y ≤ +3/4 R.
The two limiting points where i=θc satisfy x=R cos θc = R √(1-(3/4)²) = R √7/4, y = ±3/4 R.
Write the polar angle of a point on the hemisphere as φ = arctan(y/x), measured from the +x-axis.
At the two limiting points φmax = +θc, φmin = -θc.
The transparent portion of the curved surface is the arc subtended by the angle Δφ = φmax - φmin = 2θc.
Arc length: L_transparent = R Δφ = 2R θc = 2R arcsin(3/4) ≈ (2)(0.848) R ≈ 1.70 R.
Only the central 1.70 R-long arc of the hemispherical surface must be transparent; regions above y=+3/4R and below y=-3/4R can be left opaque or coated.
